name: Arabic Classical Music
description: Arabic Classical Music tradition, whose guidelines for modulation, rhythm, and tuning were set down in treatises in the 8th and 9th centuries, based around Islamic Modal Music.

children.name: Andalusian Classical Music
children.description: Found primarily in the Andalusia region in southern Spain, generally thought to have beginnings in the Emirate of Cordoba during the period of Muslim control of the region in the 9th century.

children.name: Iraqi Maqam
children.description: Highly structured but semi-improvised and rhythmically complex compositions built around set structures which consist of specific maqam modes.

children.name: Sawt
children.description: Poetic vocal form with complex rhythms, emotive singing, and distinctive lute-backed melodies commonly found in the Gulf region and based on a maqam system.

name: Azerbaijani Mugham
description: Highly improvisational form of modal music characterized by the singing style and the themes of Azerbaijan’s history.

name: East Asian Classical Music
description: Covers all the forms of pan-East Asian Classical Music sharing origins in Chinese Classical Music.

children.name: Chinese Classical Music
children.description: Classical Music of China, encompassing royal court music as well as the Chinese Opera musical theatre traditions.

children.name: Baisha xiyue
children.description: Mainly performed for funeral ceremonies of the Naxi ethnic group in the Yunnan province in China.

children.name: Chinese Opera
children.description: Traditional Chinese theatre, existing in several regional variations, combining traditional instruments and vocals along with other art forms like Poetry, dance, acrobatics, and martial arts.

children.name: Cantonese Opera
children.description: Chinese Opera that are sung in Cantonese.

children.name: Henan Opera
children.description: Originated in the central Chinese province of Henan, known for its fast-paced, easy to understand dialogue, high pitched singing and strong rhythm.

children.name: Peking Opera
children.description: Distinguishable from most types of Chinese opera by its instrumentation, 2 distinct types of melodies, and alternative Chinese pronunciation.

children.name: Korean Revolutionary Opera
children.description: Heavily influenced by Chinese Revolutionary Opera and supported by the North Korean government.

children.name: Revolutionary Opera
children.description: Popular during China's Cultural Revolution and upholds China's working class and the People's Liberation Army as the forces that brought socialism to China.

children.name: Shaoxing Opera
children.description: Exclusively performed by women in modern times with a focus on lyricism.

children.name: Yangzhou Opera
children.description: Originated in Yangzhou, and popular in some parts of Jiangsu and Anhui province, as well as Shanghai.

children.name: Dongjing
children.description: Chinese Taoist ritual music from the Nakhi (Naxi) people, historically performed around Yunnan and Sichuan.

children.name: Yayue
children.description: Incorporates folk and religious traditions of Chinese Music; literally translated as 'elegant music'.

children.name: Japanese Classical Music
children.description: Classical music of Japan.

children.name: Gagaku
children.description: One of the oldest forms of Japanese Classical Music, based on the pentatonic Yo scale, characterized by an elegant sound that is typically solemn, slow-paced, and resonant.

children.name: Heikyoku
children.description: Semi-classical bardic tradition in Japan analogous to the troubadour music of medieval Europe.

children.name: Honkyoku
children.description: Japanese Classical Music performed solo on a bamboo flute shakuhachi.

children.name: Jiuta
children.description: Originally created by solo performers singing and playing shamisen, but since the late 18th century increasingly often performed by sankyoku ensembles (shamisen, koto and shakuhachi or kokyu).

children.name: Jōruri
children.description: Consists of a singing narrator (tayū) with shamisen accompaniment.

children.name: Meiji shinkyoku
children.description: Meiji-era compositions, using a distinctive, brighter scale, usually performed with two kotos.

children.name: Nagauta
children.description: Japanese Classical Music used in Kabuki, a form of theatre oriented to dance-drama.

children.name: Noh
children.description: Played by an hayashi ensemble, consisting of a fue (flute), a kotsuzumi (shoulder drum), a ōtsuzumi (hip drum), and a taiko (stick drum).

children.name: Shōmyō
children.description: Japanese Buddhist chant that utilizes the yō scale.

children.name: Sōkyoku
children.description: Gained popularity during the Edo period, played with a koto or a guzheng and sometimes accompanied by shamisen and/or shakuhachi.

children.name: Danmono
children.description: Sōkyoku composed for koto, a thirteen-string traditional instrument.

children.name: Kumiuta
children.description: Typically performed by a single singer playing koto or less often shamisen for accompaniment, often with lyrics adapted from classical poetry.

children.name: Korean Classical Music
children.description: Classical Music of Korea.

children.name: Aak
children.description: Korean Classical Music that dates back to the early 12th century.

children.name: Dang-ak
children.description: Korean Classical Music that dates back to the Later Silla period of 668–935.

children.name: Hyang-ak
children.description: One of the most common and oldest surviving forms of Korean court music.

children.name: Jeong-ak
children.description: Also known as proper music; dates back to the Later Silla period of 668–935.

children.name: Gagok
children.description: Vocal songs derived from Korean Classical Music backed by a small orchestra of Jeong-ak ("aristocratic or proper music").

children.name: Vietnamese Classical Music
children.description: Traditional court music of Vietnam, often performed by a twelve-instrument ensemble (for Dai Nhac music) or a fourteen-instrument ensemble (for Nha Nhac music).

children.name: Ca trù
children.description: Sung poetry from northern Vietnam, performed by a female vocalist to the accompaniment of a three-stringed lute and percussion.

children.name: Vietnamese Opera
children.description: Classical musical theatre and its associated form of Vietnamese Classical Music, related strongly to Chinese Opera.

name: Inkiranya
description: Influential drumming style originating in Burundi carried out by a percussion ensemble.

name: Minyue
description: Modernized composition for Chinese instruments on the basis of Chinese Folk Music, incorporating aspects of Western Classical Music.

name: Persian Classical Music
description: Traditional art music of the Persian civilization.

name: Pìobaireachd
description: Art tradition which originated in the Scottish Highlands, usually associated with the Great Highland bagpipes.

name: Shashmaqam
description: Modal suite that brings together lyrical and instrumental songs, poetry, and dance shared by Tajik Music and Uzbek Music.

name: South Asian Classical Music
description: Meta-genre that covers the diverse forms of Classical Music from South Asia.

children.name: Carnatic Classical Music
children.description: Culture shared by the Dravidian cultures in South India separate from regional folk genres.

children.name: Hindustani Classical Music
children.description: North Indian traditional music (including parts of Pakistan, Afghanistan, Nepal, Bangladesh, and Bhutan) with roots reaching back to the 12th century CE.

children.name: Dhrupad
children.description: Ancient style of Classical Indian vocal and instrumental music.

children.name: Kafi
children.description: Sufi vocal style popular in Pakistan, differentiated from Qawwali by its small ensemble size and simple arrangements.

children.name: Khyal
children.description: Style of Hindustani Classical Music, derived from a vocal form.

children.name: Qawwali
children.description: Sufi Music in India and Pakistan using the raga and tala templates of Hindustani Classical Music.

children.name: Shabad kirtan
children.description: Religious Sikh Hymns backed by specially selected ragas and taal.

children.name: Thumri
children.description: Hindustani classical style based on North Indian folk literature.

children.name: Odissi Classical Music
children.description: Traditional dance and classical music from the Odisha region of Eastern India.

name: Southeast Asian Classical Music
description: Formal music developed in Southeast Asian countries (Burma, Cambodia, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, East Timor, Brunei Darussalam) usually in form of gong-chime orchestras such as gamelan, kulintang and pi phat.

children.name: Burmese Classical Music
children.description: Traditional court music of Myanmar, developed from Southeast Asian, Hindu and Chinese influences.

children.name: Gamelan
children.description: Originated in the island of Java; played by an ensemble typically consisting of metallophones and gongs, sometimes augmented with drums, flutes, and human voices.

children.name: Balinese Gamelan
children.description: Broad classification grouping various forms of Gamelan with native roots in Bali.

children.name: Gamelan angklung
children.description: Takes its name from the angklung, an instrument made of bamboo tubes.

children.name: Gamelan beleganjur
children.description: Loud, chaotic, highly percussive, and with heavy tempo changes.

children.name: Gamelan gender wayang
children.description: Performed with two/four metallophones made out of bronze keys with suspended bamboo tube resonators connected to them.

children.name: Gamelan gong gede
children.description: Ceremonial style characterized by a simpler and more melodic approach with clearer and more stable progressions compared to other Balinese orchestras.

children.name: Gamelan gong kebyar
children.description: Free compositional techniques and rapidly changing dynamics.

children.name: Gamelan jegog
children.description: Played entirely on marimba-like instruments made from bamboo which widely differ in size.

children.name: Gamelan selonding
children.description: Ensemble consists of four to six musicians playing metallophones made out of iron in a seven-tone scale.

children.name: Gamelan semar pegulingan
children.description: Originated in the 16th-17th centuries; features a soft, delicate, and ethereal sound.

children.name: Gamelan degung
children.description: Sundanese Gamelan performed by a small orchestra of bronze gongs and metallophones.

children.name: Javanese Gamelan
children.description: Broad classification grouping Gamelan genres native to Javanese culture.

children.name: Gamelan sekaten
children.description: Javanese ceremonial Gamelan played with large instruments, strictly unaccompanied by vocals.

children.name: Malay Gamelan
children.description: Developments of Gamelan that are performed by Malay native groups, mostly established by the Pahang and Terengganu royal courts of the Malay Peninsula.

children.name: Kacapi suling
children.description: Sundanese music played by an ensemble consisting of one or two kacapis (zithers), one suling (flute), and occasionally a set of kendangs (drums).

children.name: Kulintang
children.description: Southeast Asian gong-chime ensemble consisting mainly of gong-chimes of various sizes, with the addition of larger gongs, various drums, and occasionally xylophones and non-percussion instruments.

children.name: Mahori
children.description: Thai and Khmer traditional orchestra combining xylophones and gong-chimes of Piphat/Pinpeat with strings of Khrueang sai ensemble.

children.name: Malay Classical Music
children.description: Traditionally played in the royal courts of the several Malay kingdoms, empires and sultanates that existed throughout history.

children.name: Malay Gamelan
children.description: Developments of Gamelan that are performed by Malay native groups, mostly established by the Pahang and Terengganu royal courts of the Malay Peninsula.

children.name: Pinpeat
children.description: Orchestra of wind and percussion instruments having its origins in the Khmer Empire era.

children.name: Saluang klasik
children.description: Played by a duo or a trio of musicians, including a saluang (a kind of end-blown bamboo flute) player and a traditional singer.

children.name: Talempong
children.description: Gong-chime ensemble focused around the talempong kettle gong.

children.name: Tembang Sunda Cianjuran
children.description: Sung free-verse poetry in Sundanese language, usually by a solo vocalist, accompanied by a mellow-sounding Kacapi suling ensemble.

children.name: Thai Classical Music
children.description: Emerged from the royal courts of Central Thailand around the 13th century, based on a traditional Thai sound-scale of seven tempered notes.

children.name: Fon leb
children.description: Traditional performance music originating in northern Thailand consist of an ensemble with Piphat instruments and a pair of female choreographers.

children.name: Khrueang sai
children.description: Thai Classical Music emphasizing string instruments while also incorporating other kinds of instruments to enrich the sound.

children.name: Piphat
children.description: Led by wind and percussion instruments, with ensembles ranging from 6 to 10 instruments.

name: Sufiana kalam
description: Classical music of the Kashmir region, the northernmost part of the Indian subcontinent.

name: Turkish Classical Music
description: Classical music of Turkey, which uses the makam modal system, with the primary emphasis often being on the singers, who are accompanied by small ensembles.

children.name: Turkish Mevlevi Music
children.description: Traditional music performed among Turkish practitioners of the Mevlevi order of Sufism.

name: Western Classical Music
description: Broad range of art music associated with the aristocracy that originated in Europe around 500 AD.

children.name: Art Song
children.description: Vocal music with text often set to Poetry, typically for single vocalist with instrumental accompaniment, distinguished by its design for concert recital and high artistic demands requiring classically trained musicians.

children.name: Elizabethan Song
children.description: Monophonic style developed in Renaissance England that is typically composed in strophic form for one to several vocalists with instrumental accompaniment ranging from solo lute to chamber ensemble.

children.name: Lied
children.description: Form of song arising from 19th century German Romanticism, usually for solo vocalist & piano with a text derived from poetry.

children.name: Mélodie
children.description: French form typically with a greater emphasis on emotional restraint, refinement, subtlety, and concision.

children.name: Orchestral Song
children.description: Classical song for solo voice or voices with orchestral accompaniment.

children.name: Ballet
children.description: Western art music, often Orchestral, written to accompany classical dance productions of the same name.

children.name: Ballet de cour
children.description: Earliest form developed by the French royal court and characterized by its artistic diversity, regimented structure, grand spectacle, and overt political elements.

children.name: Opéra-ballet
children.description: Principally French style of musical drama that combines operatic singing with classical dance, usually with small Orchestral accompaniment.

children.name: Baroque Music
children.description: Constant rhythmic flow, or a steady motion throughout, generally focusing on a single melodic idea and including some form of counterpoint.

children.name: Ballet de cour
children.description: Earliest form developed by the French royal court and characterized by its artistic diversity, regimented structure, grand spectacle, and overt political elements.

children.name: Opéra-ballet
children.description: Principally French style of musical drama that combines operatic singing with classical dance, usually with small Orchestral accompaniment.

children.name: Zarzuela barroca
children.description: Earliest form that draws from a broad range of artistic sources, including theater, operatic singing, instrumental music, dance, popular music, poetry, and comedy.

children.name: Baroque Suite
children.description: Collection of varied dance pieces, usually in the same key, structured on the music of European courtly dances.

children.name: Brazilian Classical Music
children.description: Originated in the late 19th century, taking the European music that had been brought to the country by colonists and brought in parts of Brazilian Music.

children.name: Valsa brasileira
children.description: Brazillian Waltz characterized by its slow rhythms and romantic sound.

children.name: Byzantine Music
children.description: Music from Byzantine era.

children.name: Byzantine Chant
children.description: Liturgical chant of Christian churches following the Orthodox rite.

children.name: Cantata
children.description: Vocal style for solo singers with instrumental & Choral accompaniment comparable to Oratorio, though often smaller in scale, more songlike, and with less focus on dramatic narrative.

children.name: Chamber Music
children.description: Western Classical Music performed by a small ensemble, usually only a few performers.

children.name: Choral
children.description: Choir-sung classical works covering periods from medieval music (an early form being Gregorian Chant) up to present day.

children.name: Choral Concerto
children.description: Composition for unaccompanied choir, set to sacred texts of Eastern Orthodox tradition.

children.name: Choral Symphony
children.description: Combines symphonic Orchestral forces & structure with vocal parts for choir.

children.name: Mass
children.description: Composition for choir, with or without instrumental accompaniment, that sets to music text from the liturgy of the Eucharist, principally from the Latin rites of the Roman Catholic Church.

children.name: Requiem
children.description: Musical setting commemorating the deceased with text usually derived from the Roman Catholic mass of the dead.

children.name: Cinematic Classical
children.description: Orchestral compositions generally associated with soundtracks to modern high-budget films, games, and other non-live media.

children.name: Epic Music
children.description: Often associated with Electronic production, heavy percussion such as taiko drums, Choral vocals, and orchestral instrumentation to create a bombastic style commonly linked to movie trailers.

children.name: Spaghetti Western
children.description: Pioneered by Ennio Morricone with his compositions in the mid-1960s for films in the Italian Spaghetti Western genre.

children.name: Classical March
children.description: Strong and regular rhythm originally written to walk in step easier or to back events like parades or marches.

children.name: Circus March
children.description: Marches composed for use in circuses, one of the most popular forms of entertainment in the early 20th century.

children.name: Dobrado
children.description: Brazilian musical genre, played by military bands with wooden, brass and also percussive instruments.

children.name: Funeral March
children.description: Slow, solemn marches usually in a minor key; meant to invoke the feeling of a funeral procession.

children.name: Classical Period
children.description: Refers to the phase in Western Classical Music history occurring from roughly 1750 to 1820, characterized by its emphasis on clarity, simplicity, and balance.

children.name: Divertissement
children.description: Straightforward tuneful music historically written to serve as light entertainment for events or as interstitial movements within larger theatrical works.

children.name: Étude
children.description: Composition written to both showcase & sharpen a particular playing or compositional technique, often requiring great skill from its performers.

children.name: Fantasia
children.description: Free-form, improvisational, and with contrasting sectional writing, sometimes based on preexisting melodies and generally meant to evoke a sense of imaginative exploration.

children.name: Latin American Classical Music
children.description: Western Classical Music with influences from Hispanic American Music.

children.name: Madrigal
children.description: Secular polyphonic music based around poetry and generally performed by unaccompanied vocal ensembles of two to eight persons.

children.name: Medieval Classical Music
children.description: Composed during the Medieval period lasted approximately from the 5th to the late 15th centuries.

children.name: Ars antiqua
children.description: Mainly sacred European medieval music from the period of 1170 to 1310, featuring the birth of measuring time in music and the use of polyphonies for four voices.

children.name: Ars nova
children.description: Period (around 1310-1380) that succeeded Ars antiqua, mixing the sacred with the secular.

children.name: Ars subtilior
children.description: Emerged in the final period of late medieval music (around 1380-1420) and continued to use the technique of isorhythms but with added complexity.

children.name: Medieval Lyric Poetry
children.description: Lyric poetry from Medieval Europe, roughly from the 11th to the 14th century, most prominently the troubadours of southern France.

children.name: Plainsong
children.description: Monophonic chanting in the context of Roman Catholic and modern Anglican liturgy.

children.name: Ambrosian Chant
children.description: Liturgical chant practiced in parts of Italy and Switzerland, characterized by stepped melodic progression.

children.name: Canto beneventano
children.description: Extinct plainchant tradition of Southern Italy characterized by lengthy melodies, extensive use of repetition, and a steady, undulating progression.

children.name: Canto mozárabe
children.description: Iberian form of plainchant that flourished roughly 550-1085 AD.

children.name: Celtic Chant
children.description: Extinct tradition of Catholic liturgical chant developed by the Celtic Christians of Britain, Ireland, and Brittany.

children.name: Gregorian Chant
children.description: Liturgical, monophonic chant that accompanied Mass and other rituals in Western Christianity.

children.name: Old Roman Chant
children.description: Plainchant tradition of Medieval Rome that was closely related to Gregorian Chant, though often more musically ornate.

children.name: Modern Classical
children.description: Multitude of different compositional approaches beginning in the 20th century that deviate significantly from the previously-held tenets.

children.name: Expressionism
children.description: Originating between the abandonment of tonality at the conclusion of the period of Romanticism and the creation of twelve-tone composition.

children.name: Futurism
children.description: Radical and militant attitude, rejection of Western Classical Music and traditional criteria of craft, non-conformity, and a fascination with machines.

children.name: Impressionism
children.description: Originated in late 19th to early 20th century France as a reaction to Romanticism.

children.name: Indeterminacy
children.description: Leaves elements of composition, performance, or both up to chance.

children.name: Microtonal Classical
children.description: Eschews the traditional twelve-tone scale of Western Classical Music, utilizing intervals outside of its bounds.

children.name: Minimalism
children.description: Developed in the United States in the 1960s; recognized for its repetitive nature and use of static harmony.

children.name: Holy Minimalism
children.description: Style informed by Christian Liturgical Music that emphasizes slow sustained rhythmic values, soft dynamics, and silence to produce a contemplative and reverential atmosphere.

children.name: Musique concrète instrumentale
children.description: Acoustic, through-composed Classical Music that relies heavily on unconventional instrumental techniques.

children.name: New Complexity
children.description: Dense, difficult, and rigorously academic approach to Modern Classical composition which emerged in the 1980s.

children.name: Post-Minimalism
children.description: Seeks to push Minimalism's linear composition style forward, and takes in influences from genres such as Jazz, Traditional Folk Music, and others.

children.name: Totalism
children.description: Adds complex rhythmic structures and emphasis on surface energy to Minimalism.

children.name: Serialism
children.description: Compositional method in which pitches are grouped into sets (tone rows) to determine the order and frequency of their use.

children.name: Integral Serialism
children.description: Application of twelve-tone technique in early Serialism to as many compositional factors as possible (in an attempt to apply total serial control).

children.name: Sonorism
children.description: Techniques and forms that emphasize texture and timbre.

children.name: Spectralism
children.description: Compositional practice involving analysis, manipulation, and transformation of sound spectra.

children.name: Stochastic Music
children.description: Composition featuring guided indeterminism, where the following state is only partially determined by the preceding state.

children.name: Motet
children.description: Extremely diverse form of vocal music, usually written as a style of Polyphonic Chant for A cappella soloists or choir.

children.name: Neoclassicism
children.description: Return to the more formal and less expansive structures and forms, beginning shortly after World War I as a reaction to what some composers perceived as excesses of Romanticism.

children.name: Nocturne
children.description: Intimate character piece meant to evoke associations with the night, usually written for solo piano.

children.name: Opera
children.description: European tradition which combines drama and distinctive vocal style in the context of Western Classical Music, usually performed as a theatrical work on stage.

children.name: Ballad Opera
children.description: English reaction to the Italian Opera styles with a satirical sense of humor and scores borrowing from Traditional Folk Music and popular music.

children.name: Grand opéra
children.description: French style characterized by its enlarged scope and sense of grandeur, with bigger orchestras and casts, and ornate sceneries and costumes.

children.name: Monodrama
children.description: Mostly modern style written for a single virtuoso singer with accompaniment, often shorter in length and with a more philosophically introspective or abstract libretto.

children.name: Opéra-ballet
children.description: Principally French style of musical drama that combines operatic singing with classical dance, usually with small Orchestral accompaniment.

children.name: Opera buffa
children.description: Lighthearted and amusing counterpart to Opera seria; developed in Naples in the first half of the 18th century.

children.name: Opéra-comique
children.description: French style of Opera characterized by the use of some spoken dialogues to connect major arias and sung parts, as well as a more restrained approach to recitatives.

children.name: Opera semiseria
children.description: Popular in the early and middle 19th century, containing appeals to emotion of Opera seria as well as some comedy elements present in Opera buffa.

children.name: Opera seria
children.description: Italian Opera popular among European nobility and royalty throughout most of the 18th century, typified by its exaggerated dramatic flair and interspersed with dry recitative.

children.name: Operetta
children.description: Light opera interspersed with spoken dialogues, being usually satirical and/or humorous in nature and centered around romantic plots and dancing scenes.

children.name: Kalon'ny fahiny
children.description: Fusion of music from the highlands of Madagascar and western Operetta.

children.name: Romantische Oper
children.description: Early 19th century Germanic style of Opera influenced by German Folk Music and legends with a focus on fantasy, emotivity, heroic figures, and nationalism.

children.name: Singspiel
children.description: German form of Opera distinguished by the prominent usage of spoken dialogues mixed with lyrical or folklore arias/ballads.

children.name: Tragédie en musique
children.description: French Opera genre developed by Jean-Baptiste Lully and Philippe Quinault in the second half of the 17th century, consisting of alterations made to the coeval Italian format to better fit the French language and please an audience more accustomed to the ballet de cour.

children.name: Verismo
children.description: Developed in Italy around the turn of the 20th century and favored melodramatic realism, a rejection of bel canto standards, and declamatory singing.

children.name: Zarzuela
children.description: Spanish dramatic genre where spoken scenes are mixed with passages sung in operatic or popular styles.

children.name: Género chico
children.description: Light, small-scale musical comedy with mild social commentary, populist themes, and catchy melodies.

children.name: Zarzuela barroca
children.description: Earliest form that draws from a broad range of artistic sources, including theater, operatic singing, instrumental music, dance, popular music, poetry, and comedy.

children.name: Zarzuela grande
children.description: Romantic musical comedy akin to Operetta developed during the mid-19th century.

children.name: Zeitoper
children.description: Short-lived scene in Weimar Germany, often having satirical plots and allusions to popular music.

children.name: Oratorio
children.description: Composition for vocal soloists, choir, and orchestra, often making use of a comprehensive textbook of contemplative nature.

children.name: Orchestral
children.description: Western Classical Music performed by an orchestra, often a full size Symphony orchestra.

children.name: Concert Band
children.description: Music for large ensemble of woodwinds, brass, and percussion.

children.name: Concerto
children.description: Multi-movement Classical works for orchestra and one or more soloists.

children.name: Concerto for Orchestra
children.description: Mostly modern form in which virtuosic solo passages are alternately played among different portions of the orchestra.

children.name: Concerto grosso
children.description: Oldest form developed during the Baroque Music era in which the body of the music is alternately shared between a small group of soloists and a larger orchestra.

children.name: Sinfonia concertante
children.description: Fuses symphonic compositional structure and instrumentation with parts written for concertante soloists.

children.name: Orchestral Song
children.description: Classical song for solo voice or voices with orchestral accompaniment.

children.name: Symphony
children.description: Large-scale Western Classical Music works for orchestra, typically with four movements: 1) allegro, almost always in sonata-allegro form 2) a slow movement 3) scherzo or minuet 4) finale, typically allegro or rondo.

children.name: Choral Symphony
children.description: Combines symphonic Orchestral forces & structure with vocal parts for choir.

children.name: Sinfonia concertante
children.description: Fuses symphonic compositional structure and instrumentation with parts written for concertante soloists.

children.name: Tone Poem
children.description: Programmatic work for orchestra, usually in a single movement, that is entirely based on external non-musical themes, ideas, tales, stories, etc.

children.name: Overture
children.description: Typically single-movement form akin to the Tone Poem written as the prelude to a larger work or in association with a programmatic concept.

children.name: Prelude
children.description: Brief work with an improvisatory feeling, usually for keyboard, that serves either as a standalone piece or an introduction to a complimentary work of music.

children.name: Renaissance Music
children.description: Encompasses Western Classical Music from the 15th to 16th centuries.

children.name: Elizabethan Song
children.description: Monophonic style developed in Renaissance England that is typically composed in strophic form for one to several vocalists with instrumental accompaniment ranging from solo lute to chamber ensemble.

children.name: Ricercar
children.description: Early instrumental genre, usually for solo lute or keyboard, written either as a brief introductory work or imitative contrapuntal piece.

children.name: Romanticism
children.description: Expressive and emotional qualities, especially in terms of melody.

children.name: Grand opéra
children.description: French style characterized by its enlarged scope and sense of grandeur, with bigger orchestras and casts, and ornate sceneries and costumes.

children.name: Romantische Oper
children.description: Early 19th century Germanic style of Opera influenced by German Folk Music and legends with a focus on fantasy, emotivity, heroic figures, and nationalism.

children.name: Serenade
children.description: Light, tuneful, and relatively straightforward music historically associated with outdoor entertainment for evening gatherings.

children.name: Sonata
children.description: Broad instrumental genre for one to three soloists that has changed significantly throughout its history, now typically a suite of four or fewer contrasting movements, at least one of which is written in sonata form.

children.name: Spanish Classical Music
children.description: Incorporation of Spanish Music within the context of Western Classical Music, particularly characterized by the use of the classical guitar.

children.name: Canto mozárabe
children.description: Iberian form of plainchant that flourished roughly 550-1085 AD.

children.name: Zarzuela
children.description: Spanish dramatic genre where spoken scenes are mixed with passages sung in operatic or popular styles.

children.name: Género chico
children.description: Light, small-scale musical comedy with mild social commentary, populist themes, and catchy melodies.

children.name: Zarzuela barroca
children.description: Earliest form that draws from a broad range of artistic sources, including theater, operatic singing, instrumental music, dance, popular music, poetry, and comedy.

children.name: Zarzuela grande
children.description: Romantic musical comedy akin to Operetta developed during the mid-19th century.

children.name: Toccata
children.description: Virtuoso piece, usually for solo keyboard or plucked string instrument, characterized by its free rhythm, rapid fingerwork, and contrasting sectional writing.
